properties.description: “It is our microclimate here that makes Turkish tea so special,” said Hasan. “The snow in winter stops the insects and diseases. So we don’t need pesticides. We are a natural product.” The buyer looked out of the window across the fields, where two women, wrapped tightly against the mountain cold, bent over the bushes. “Of course,” Hasan continued, “You also get a special price, yes? We have no auction, you come to us, you get a special price. Direct, yes, it is good for the business.” He took a sip from the glass in front of him. “Ahhhhh.”
properties.title: tea producer

properties.description: The sun beat down on Abasi as he bent over the tea bush. He could feel the roughness of the wicker basket pressing down through his loose, ill-fitting shirt. The bushes weren’t so healthy after the frost, most of the young shoots shrivelled, dead on the branches. He picked around the damage, but his load was much smaller than it usually would be so near the end of the day. The frosts were getting harsher - and the days hotter - he was sure. As the light failed he headed back to the warehouse to deposit the tea. He greeted some colleagues warmly, discussing the frost, and the impact it was having on the small farm. There was talk of wage cuts - down from 200-odd shillings per day closer to the minimum of 178.8. He left for home worried. His family could barely get by on his earnings as it was.
properties.title: tea producer

properties.description: “Ah, Ceylon! How about Sri Lanka?” Anna remembered how she’d squeeled. Who’d have thought that her random clicking would have come up with such a perfect place for their holiday? As she lay next to Ryan now, under the mosquito blanket, in their luxurious bed in a Colonial bungalow, she grinned. That morning she’d found a tiny box in his suitcase while she was unpacking. This was it - she could imagine it now. They’d cycle through the tea fields - is that what they called them? - get to the top of one of those beautiful mountains, and that’d be where he’d do it. “Anna, will you marry me?” She could barely conceal her excitement.
properties.title: tea producer

properties.description: Nileem and Alpa filed into the tea garden. “Did you hear about the riots at the Bhattacharya place?” asked Nileem. Alpa, looking away, shook her head, returned her gaze to her companion and answered “no”, disinterestedly. “The Konapathar plantation,” Nileem continued. “The owner and his wife were killed. There were riots, complaints about not being paid enough. The workers ended up setting fire to the place. But you know, I heard some of them even ate the bodies. Ate them!” Alpa looked horrified. “I do feel the anger rising,” she mused. “I hear talk of riots everywhere.”

properties.description: The dismal, branded, beige and blue building squats on concrete legs amidst eucalyptus trees. Building, road, fences, trees, everything is covered by the incessant dust as the trucks trundle in and out. Disinterested people coast by in cars that have seen better days. Can joy help but be stifled in this ugly wasteland?

properties.description: Sarah wasn’t having a great day. She was tired because Elvis had been awake most of the night. He’d cried most of the day too. Now she was out running errands when all she wanted to do was sleep, just like Elvis was doing now in the baby seat of the Cosco trolley. What did she need again? She could barely remember. Sweet potatoes she had, jelly... tea. Yeah she could do with some tea. Which one though? Hey that Lipton will do - doesn’t everybody drink Lipton? Nice and cheap too. She tossed a packet into the trolley behind Elvis and went in search of her mind.
